title: Suns' Deandre Ayton suspended 25 games for violating NBA anti-drug policy
text:
CLOSE

No one was more excited about Wednesday's season opener than Deandre Ayton.

"I'm just ready to explode, to be honest," he said before the game. "I don't even know how to express it."

The Phoenix Suns proceeded to blast the Sacramento Kings, showing the potential they posses under new head coach Monty Williams.

Less than 24 hours later, their hopes for having an improved season took a major hit.

The NBA has suspended Ayton for 25 games without pay for "violating the terms of the NBA/NBPA Anti-Drug Program by testing positive for a diuretic," the league announced Thursday.

"I want to apologize to my family, the entire Suns organization, my teammates, partners, our fans and the Phoenix community," Ayton said in a statement Thursday night. "This was an unintentional mistake and unfortunately I put something in my body that I was completely unaware of.

"I do understand the unfortunate impact that this has on so many others, and for that I am deeply sorry. I‘m extremely disappointed that I’ve let my team down.

"I will continue to work with the Player's Union (NBPA) to go through the arbitration process and am hopeful for a positive resolution."

Ayton's suspension begins Friday's when the Suns take on the Denver Nuggets.

The NBPA is reportedly planning to file for arbitration of Ayton's suspension. The players' association believes Ayton's suspension is eligible to be reduced because of an "unintentional ingestion" provision, league sources told ESPN. The NBPA could not be immediately reached to confirm the report.

Suns general manager James Jones said in a statement the team was "disappointed" with Ayton.

"This does not uphold the standards and principles we have set for the team," Jones said. "... Deandre has expressed his deepest remorse. While he is suspended we remain committed to his growth and development on and off the court. His actions are not taken lightly, and we are committed to ensuring that Deandre understands the profound impact it has had on the team, organization, and Suns community."

The No. 1 overall pick in the 2018 NBA draft out of Arizona, Ayton had 18 points with 11 rebounds in Wednesday night's win over the Kings at Talking Stick Resort Arena.

As a rookie, Ayton averaged 16.2 points with 10.3 rebounds and posted a Suns rookie-record 39 double-doubles in 71 games.

Ayton looked to have a major sophomore season. Instead, the Suns will be playing without their starting center against quality teams, and facing elite big men in Joel Embiid (Sixers) Karl-Anthony Towns (Timberwolves), Anthony Davis (Lakers), Nikola Jokic (Nuggets) and Rudy Gobert (Jazz).

How Phoenix plays without Ayton may be an even greater challenge.

The Suns could start Aron Baynes at center, but could also go with Frank Kaminsky III. Baynes is the more physical of the two, but Kaminsky is a bigger threat offensively.

The Suns are capable of scoring points without Ayton and may play their share of small ball, but they'll miss his rebounding and presence in the paint. Ayton blocked four shots in Wednesday's win.

Contributing: Jeff Zillgitt.
description: The league informed the Suns that Ayton, the top pick in the 2018 draft, tested positive for a diuretic. His suspension begins Friday.
